awd_titl_txt: Effect of Alloying and Thermo-Mechanical Processing on the Deformation of Hexagonal Close-Packed Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
Hexagonal close-packed (HCP) metals such as titanium, magnesium and zirconium alloys are commonly used for structural applications in energy, transportation and biomedical technologies, and a thorough understanding of their mechanical integrity is central for their in-service sustainability. Correlating fine-scale structure of the alloys with their resistance to deformation at service temperatures will allow for new understanding of the mechanisms that control alloy performance, and can provide guidance for design of high-strength, durable components. This award supports fundamental scientific research to understand the role of alloy composition and structure on mechanical properties in zirconium-based alloys. The research brings experimental testing together with computational modeling to predict the behavior of these alloys based on the new knowledge of their composition, structure, and how these relate to properties and performance in service. The work will lead to new scientific understanding that can be applied to a number of important alloy systems, and will provide excellent educational opportunities for students participating in the research. Particular emphasis is placed on broadening participation in scientific research through engagement in K-12 outreach programs which will allow high school students the opportunity to participate in the research, along with undergraduate and graduate students.

This research addresses the influence of thermo-mechanical treatment and alloying on creep anisotropy of zirconium alloys with emphasis on niobium addition and heat treatment. The addition of niobium as an alloying element has been shown to lend better performance and durability, and this research aims to understand the phenomena controlling this behavior. Creep anisotropies in these alloys will be investigated in the different regimes such as power-law and viscous creep, as well as at high stresses in the power-law breakdown region. Corresponding deformation microstructures will be characterized for a thorough understanding of the underlying creep mechanisms and the biaxial creep anisotropy. The knowledge derived from this research can be applied to understand the plastic deformation mechanisms of other HCP alloys at high temperatures, and can provide robust tools to predict dimensional changes in service. This research involves both experimental and modeling approaches, and the findings will be integrated into classroom teaching for training the next generation of Engineers.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
A major objective of the grant is to characterize the effect of thermo-mechanical treatment on creep anisotropy of Zr-based alloys used for nuclear reactors as thin-walled tubing to contain radioactive fuel pellets. Main emphasis here has been to characterize the effect of Nb additions on the mechanical response due to internal pressurization along with superimposed axial load at high temperatures. A major aim of the project has been to investigate the effect of heat treatment on their creep (time dependent deformation under given temperature and load) behaviors in particular the directional dependence known as anisotropy. Elongated grain structures in the as-received tubing are seen to result in equiaxed grain structures following thermal treatment (recrystallization) that is expected to lead to different deformation anisotropies.

A biaxial creep machine was used for testing tube samples with internal pressurization superimposed with axial load. The biaxial creep behaviors of as-received Zr-Nb alloys (HANA4 and Zirlo) have been investigated by two MS students at 500 and 400 0C respectively. The effect of thermal treatment on Zirlo tubing was investigated by a doctoral student at varied temperatures that clearly revealed the fact that the hoop (diametral) direction became stronger following thermal treatment (recrystallization). The project supported 6 undergraduate students who worked along with the graduate students and got trained in carrying out experiments. The project work resulted in 6 journal publications and 4 conference presentations.

Broader Impacts

By combining experiment and modeling, if the crystal plasticity model is able to predict creep behavior of these alloys correctly, it will provide researchers with a robust tool to predict biaxial creep properties in service condition for other hcp alloys. While the proposed research is on Zr alloys used mainly in nuclear reactor and chemical technologies, the results from the proposed studies have direct applications to other hcp metals such as magnesium and titanium alloys that find wide usage in automotive and aerospace industries as well as others such as biotechnology, etc. The training of students in research will prepare them for future workforce. The procedures outlined here can be potentially followed by others in their alloy development program(s) to understand mechanism(s) of the plastic deformation at high temperatures.

 

 


Last Modified: 04/01/2023
Modified by: K. Linga Murty
